page.title: 02LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: {GARTLY}(pronounced commonly locally as "Gairtly") appears first as Grantully. The name possibly comes from Gaelic - Gareun-tully meaning "birds' field among the knoll",or from Gort-tully - "The field of the knoll (The spelling "Gortuly" also appears), or "Garadh antulaich"-The enclosure on the knoll". In any event there ARE many knolls in the Gartly area. NJ534336{DOVECOTE.}This is a rare and old example of a conical bee-hive type. It was built beside an ancient castle{THE PLACE OF GARTLY}of which now remains little more than a grassy mound over some stones. The Place of Gartly figured often during the reign of Mary Queen of Scots, as she stayed there at least twice. The last date recorded is 1682,and some time after it was burnt down reputedly by a wronged husband returning from battle.
